generif.text: Regulation of histone acetylation and transcription by nuclear protein pp32, a subunit of the INHAT complex.

LANP could play a key role in neuronal development and/or neurodegeneration by its interactions with microtubule associated proteins
Set/TAF-Ibeta and pp32 proteins have roles as transducers of chromatin signaling by integrating chromatin hypoacetylation and transcriptional repression

tyrosine phosphorylation of PHAPI is accompanied by the release of PP2A from association with PHAPI, allowing increased phosphatase activity of PP2A and consequent complete dephosphorylation of the ERK kinase, MEK1/2, by 10 min and of ERK1/2 by 60 min
We now show pp32 increases androgen receptor-mediated transcription and the retinoblastoma protein modulates this activity.
The ANP32A protein is characterizing as modulators of Wnt protein signaling of Axin-1.
pp32 plays a repressive role by inhibiting transcription and triggering apoptosis.
Immunoblot detection revealed that the inhibitor I1PP2A is expressed throughout the brain, including the hippocampus, temporal cortex, parietal cortex, subcortical nuclei and brain stem.
LANP and ATAXN1 interact in E4F-mediated transcriptional repression.

These results identify pp32/PHAPI as regulator of the apoptosis response of cancer cells in vitro and in vivo, and as a predictor of survival following chemotherapy for advanced non-small-cell lung cancer.
Results describe the solution structure of the evolutionarily conserved N-terminal leucine-rich repeat (LRR) domain of Anp32a and model its interactions with other proteins.
PHAPI, CAS, and Hsp70 function together to accelerate nucleotide exchange on Apaf-1 and prevent inactive Apaf-1/cytochrome c aggregation.
PHAPI/pp32 suppresses tumorigenesis by stimulating apoptosis.
ANP32A is involved in the pathogenesis of osteoarthritis of the hip.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)

Sphingosine interaction with acidic leucine-rich nuclear phosphoprotein-32A (ANP32A) regulates PP2A activity and cyclooxygenase (COX)-2 expression in human endothelial cells.
Observational study of gene-disease association, gene-environment interaction, and pharmacogenomic / toxicogenomic. (HuGE Navigator)
The HPPCn expression might be involved in the development of hepatocellular carcinoma and could be served as a promising biomarker.

Data provide evidence that the tumor suppressor function of pp32 can be attributed to its ability to disrupt HuR binding to target mRNAs encoding key proteins for cancer cell survival and drug efficacy.
MicroRNA-21 targets tumor suppressor genes ANP32A and SMARCA4.
pp32 interacted with STAT1 and STAT2 in an IFNB-dependent manner.
Demonstrate that HPPCn attenuated oxidative injury and fibrosis induced by ethanol feeding and that the SphK1/S1P/S1PRs signalling pathway contributes to this protective effect.
conformational analysis of the C-terminal transition state of the leucine-rich repeat domain of PP32
High-resolution crystal structure of the leucine-rich repeat domain of the human tumour suppressor PP32A (ANP32A) has been reported.
Host-derived proteins pp32 and APRIL interact with a free form of influenza virus RNA-dependent RNA polymerase and preferentially upregulates viral RNA synthesis rather than cRNA synthesis.
ANP32A represents an essential host partner co-opted to support influenza virus replication and is a candidate host target for novel antivirals

Results suggest that ANP32A is commonly increased in oral squamous cell carcinoma and ANP32A protein could act as a potential biomarker for prognosis assessment of oral cancer patients with lymph node metastasis.
ANP32A promoted CRC proliferation by inhibition of p38.
These data suggest compensatory mechanisms underlying viral Polymerase adaptation to host ANP32A independent of species-specific interactions.
Data show that PP32 and SET/TAF-Ibeta proteins block HAT1-mediated H4 acetylation.

According to the cellular function of the characterized targets of ProTalpha, and the evolution in the composition of the diverse ProTalpha-complexes when proliferation activity was reduced or apoptosis induced, leads to hypothesized that ProTalpha interactions might be related to the proliferation activity and control of the cell survival.
our study reveals that ANP32A dysregulation may be a critical factor contributing to acute megakaryoblastic leukemia
our data indicate that ANP32A is a novel regulator of histone H3 acetylation and promotes leukemogenesis.
PHAP1 expression is elevated in glioma patients, which may accelerate the proliferation of glioma cells by regulating the Akt/p27/stathmin pathway.
ANP32A/ATM axis discovered in cartilage is also present in brain and bone.
The C-terminal portion of ANP32A and the middle domains (residues 307-534) of PB2 were required for PB2-ANP32A interaction.

ANP32A and ANP32B from different species are powerful factors in the maintenance of viral polymerase activity. Human ANP32A and ANP32B contribute equally to support human influenza viral RNA replication.
Human ANP32A and ANP32B homologues both support function of human-adapted influenza polymerase but do not support efficient activity of avian IAV polymerase which requires avian ANP32A.

The contribution of minimal asparagine ladder from the leucine-rich repeat protein pp32 to stability is tested and lattice rigidity and hydrogen bond character is investigated. Point substitutions of the two ladder asparagines of pp32 are strongly destabilizing and decrease the cooperativity of unfolding. Asparagine side chains are held in a very rigid, nondynamic structure, making a significant contribution to stability.
ANP32A and ANP32B mediate the export of unspliced or partially spliced viral mRNA via interactions with Rev and CRM1.
ANP32A differentially regulates vRNA levels for species-specific effects on PB2 627E polymerase activity.

Avian ANP32A proteins harbor an additional 33 amino acids compared to human ANP32A proteins, which are crucial for their ability to support the avian-origin influenza virus polymerase. Species differences in ANP32A can restrict the host range of influenza virus.
Molecular basis of host-adaptation interactions between influenza virus polymerase PB2 subunit and ANP32A.
Host ANP32A mediates the assembly of the influenza virus replicase.
ANP32A promotes the proliferation, migration and invasion of hepatocellular carcinoma by modulating the HMGA1/STAT3 pathway.
KPNA6 is a Cofactor of ANP32A/B in Supporting Influenza Virus Polymerase Activity.
AIMP1 promotes multiple myeloma malignancy through interacting with ANP32A to mediate histone H3 acetylation.
Hypoxia and Wnt signaling inversely regulate expression of chondroprotective molecule ANP32A in articular cartilage.
Avian Influenza A Virus Polymerase Can Utilize Human ANP32 Proteins To Support cRNA but Not vRNA Synthesis.
[Silenced ANP32A inhibits the growth, invasion and migration of colorectal cancer in vitro via the inactivation of AKT pathway].
Glaucoma-Associated CDR1 Peptide Promotes RGC Survival in Retinal Explants through Molecular Interaction with Acidic Leucine Rich Nuclear Phosphoprotein 32A (ANP32A).

summary: Enables RNA binding activity. Involved in nucleocytoplasmic transport. Located in endoplasmic reticulum; nucleus; and perinuclear region of cytoplasm. [provided by Alliance of Genome Resources, Apr 2022]
